Vascular Endothelial Growth Factor Inhibits Mitogen-Induced Vascular
Smooth Muscle Cell Proliferation 1,2
Amir H. Dorafshar, M.D.,* Niren Angle, M.D.,* ,3 Michael Bryer-Ash, M.D., , Danshan Huang, M.D., ,
Michael M. Farooq, M.D.,* Hugh A. Gelabert, M.D.,* and Julie A. Freischlag, M.D.
*Division of Vascular Surgery and Division of Endocrinology, Diabetes and Hypertension, UCLA Gonda (Goldschmied) Diabetes Center,
David Geffen School of Medicine at UCLA, Los Angeles, CA; and Research Service, West Los Angeles Veterans Administration
Medical Center, Los Angeles, CA
Submitted for publication December 11, 2002
Introduction. Delivery of vascular endothelial
growth factor (VEGF) protein or gene transfer has
been shown to accelerate re-endothelialization and at-
tenuate neointimal hyperplasia in various arterial in-
jury models, including balloon injury, stent implanta-
tion, and vein grafts. In addition to stimulating re-
endothelialization, we hypothesize that VEGF has
further vascular protective functions to prevent neo-
intimal hyperplasia by directly inhibiting mitogen-
induced proliferation of vascular smooth muscle cells
(VSMCs) via the mitogen-activated protein kinase
pathway.
Materials and methods. Human aortic VSMCs were
seeded and serum starved for 24 h. The cells were then
stimulated with a mitogen, recombinant human plate-
let derived growth factor at 20 ng/mL together with 0,
10, 20, 30, 40, 50 ng/mL recombinant human VEGF. A
proliferation assay was used to quantitate bromode-
oxyuridine uptake into newly synthesized DNA. West-
ern immunoassay was used to quantify extracellular
signal-regulated kinase (ERK) 2 protein and phos-
phorylation of retinoblastoma and ERK 1/2 protein.
Results. VEGF inhibited bromodeoxyuridine incor-
poration into mitogen-induced VSMC in a dose-
dependent manner, reaching statistical significance at
concentrations of 30 (P < 0.05), 40 (P < 0.05), and 50
ng/mL (P < 0.01). Densitometry of western immuno-
blots revealed an inhibition of phosphorylation of ret-
inoblastoma at VEGF concentrations of 40 and 50
ng/mL and ERK 1/2 phosphorylation at concentrations
of 30, 40 and 50 ng/mL.
Conclusion. In addition to stimulating re-
endothelialization, VEGF appears to have a vascular
protective function by directly inhibiting VSMC pro-
liferation. This effect occurs in the absence of endo-
thelial cells and via the mitogen-activated protein ki-
nase pathway. VEGF may serve as an important
modulator of mitogen-induced VSMC proliferation af-
ter vascular injury. © 2003 Elsevier Inc. All rights reserved.
Key Words: vascular endothelial growth factor; hu-
man aortic smooth muscle; neointimal hyperplasia.
text.body:
INTRODUCTION
The treatment of arterial occlusive disease, whether
it is in the coronary, peripheral, or cerebrovascular
circulation, has evolved considerably both with regard
to operative techniques as well as angioplasty and
stenting. Although these aggressive revascularization
techniques have resulted in better outcomes, the suc-
cess of these treatments is limited by a finite failure
rate because of restenosis resulting from neointimal
hyperplasia. The incidence of this conduit failure is
high, with restenosis rates of up to 32% after coronary
stenting at 6-month follow up [1] and 31% after carotid
endarterectomy at 7 years [2].
Neointimal hyperplasia results from injury to the
endothelial lining leading to the activation and uncon-
trolled proliferation of vascular smooth muscle cells
(VSMCs) within the medial layer of the blood vessel.
VSMCs then migrate from the medial layer to the
intimal layer, secrete and deposit matrix, and cause
intimal thickening. This results in luminal narrowing

of the vessel and can eventually lead to thrombosis and
failure of the intervention or graft [3, 4].
Platelet-derived growth factor (PDGF) is produced
by endothelial cells [5], VSMCs [6], activated macro-
phages [7], and from platelets in thrombi [8] and is
thought to be important in lesion formation. Increased
expression of PDGF and PDGF receptors have been
shown in neointimal lesions after balloon catheter in-
jury [9, 10] and percutaneous transluminal coronary
angioplasty [11]. Furthermore, PDGF-BB infusion into
rats after carotid injury directly promoted neointimal
thickening [12]. PDGF binding to its receptor is known
to result in an increase of the active, GTP-bound form
of Ras [13]. This in turn activates the signaling in the
Raf/MAP kinase-ERK kinase (MEK)/extracellular
signal-regulated (ERK) kinase pathway (also known as
the mitogen-activated protein kinase [MAPK] cascade)
[14], which stimulates cyclin D1 gene transcription and
leads to phosphorylation of the retinoblastoma (Rb)
tumor suppressor protein. This phosphorylation inac-
tivates the capability of Rb to interact with the E2F
transcription factors, causing them to accumulate and
activate the transcription of a large number of genes
essential for DNA synthesis and cell cycle progression
from G1 to S phase [15]. Therefore, it is believed that
PDGF has an essential role in the tissue response to
injury by activating the MAPK cascade in VSMCs,
thereby causing cellular proliferation, migration, and
differentiation and thus the formation of a neointimal
lesion.
Vascular endothelial growth factor (VEGF) is a 46-
kDa dimeric peptide [16] that is essential for angiogen-
esis (sprouting of capillaries from preexisting vessels)
and vasculogenesis (endothelial cell differentiation)
[17, 18]. The biological effects of VEGF are mainly
regulated by two tyrosine kinase receptors, Flt-1 [19]
and Flk-1/KDR [20], the latter being important in cell
proliferation, antiapoptosis, and cell survival in endo-
thelial cells [16, 21, 22]. The angiogenic effects of
VEGF have been used clinically to stimulate collateral
artery formation in regions of tissue with vascular
deficits such as occurs with ischemic heart disease and
peripheral vascular disease [23, 24]. More recently, it
has been hypothesized that VEGF has additional vas-
cular protective properties that may be useful in the
treatment of cardiovascular occlusive diseases [25].
Specifically, it has been shown in a number of studies
that VEGF gene or protein infusion increases
re-endothelialization and therefore, it has been hy-
pothesized that as a consequence of this re-
endothelialization, neointimal hyperplasia is inhibited
[26 –30].
Evidence suggests that VEGF receptors, Flt-1 and
Flk-1/KDR, are present not only on endothelial cells
but are present on a number of other cell types [31–33].
Moreover, two independent groups have detected func-
tional VEGF receptors on VSMC that can induced mi-
gration but not proliferation [34,35]. However, the ef-
fect of VEGF on mitogen-induced VSMC proliferation
is unknown.
In this study, we show that VEGF directly inhibits
PDGF-BB-induced proliferation of VSMC using a
bromo deoxy uridine (BrdU) proliferation assay. Fur-
thermore, we show by western blotting immunoassay
that VEGF inhibits PDGF-BB-mediated phosphoryla-
tion of Rb and ERK 1/2 protein.
MATERIALS AND METHODS
Reagents
Human recombinant VEGF and PDGF-BB were obtained from
PeproTech (Rocky Hill, NJ). Human aortic VSMCs, smooth muscle
basal media (SmBM), smooth muscle growth media (SmGM) contain-
ing 0.5 g/mL hEGF, 1 g/ml hFGF, 50 mg/mL gentamicin, 50
g/mL amphotericin-B, 5 mg/mL insulin, and 5% fetal bovine serum,
0.025% tryspin/0.01% EDTA solution, trypsin neutralizing solution,
and HEPES-buffered saline solution were all-obtained from Clonet-
ics Biowhittaker (Walkersville, MD). The following monoclonal an-
tibodies were purchased: phosphorylated retinoblastoma (pRb)
(554136) from BD Biosciences Pharmingen (San Diego, CA),
-smooth muscle actin (A-2547) from Sigma (St. Louis, MO) and
ERK2 (E-4) and pERK 1/2 (D-2) from Santa Cruz Biotechnology
(Santa Cruz, CA). Supersignal Chemiluminescence kit and horserad-
ish peroxidase were purchased from Pierce (Rockford, IL). Protein
concentration assay solutions were purchased from Bio-Rad (Her-
cules, CA). Film was obtained from Eastman Kodak (Rochester, NY).
Nitrocellulose membrane was from Schleicher and Schuell (Keene,
NH). All other chemicals were purchased from Sigma (St. Louis,
MO), unless otherwise stated.
Cell Culture
VSMCs were grown in SmGM containing 5% fetal bovine serum at
37°C in 5% CO 2 and 95% ambient air. SmGM containing 5% fetal
bovine serum was used for proliferating cells and SmBM, which is
devoid of growth factors or cytokines was used for the purpose of
serum starvation. Culture medium was changed every 3 days.
Trypsin/EDTA was used with HEPES-buffered saline solution and
trypsin neutralizing solution to passage the cells. Cells were used at
passage number 3– 6. Cells were allowed to proliferate until they
reached 60 –70% confluency, at which point the SmGM was aspirated
and the media changed to SmBM to allow cell cycle synchronization.
Cells were serum-starved overnight (18 h) using SmBm and treated
the following morning. Treatment consisted of 20 ng/mL PDGF-BB
with the addition of 0, 10, 20, 30, 40, or 50 ng/ml VEGF in a solution
of SmBM for a 24-h period.
BrdU Incorporation
Cells were seeded onto a 96-well plate at 3  10 5 cells/mL, serum-
starved, and treated with the solutions stated above. A BrdU cell
proliferation assay (QIA58; Oncogene Research Products, Boston,
MA) was used per manufacturer's instructions to detect BrdU incor-
poration into dividing cells. BrdU labeling was added to each well at
the time of treatment, therefore the cells were incubated with BrdU
label for a 24-h period to allow adequate cellular uptake before
analysis. A spectrometer was used for colorimetric detection of BrdU

incorporation. In addition, in separate wells, for each treatment dose
and time point, cell viability was assessed using trypan blue exclu-
sion.
Western Blot Analysis
VSMC were plated at 2–3  10 5 cells/well in 100-mm 2 culture
dishes. After serum starvation and treatment with various solutions,
liquid N 2 was added. Two-hundred microliters of RIPA buffer (50
mM Tris-HCL, pH 7.4, 150 mM NaCl, 0.5% deoxycholate, and 1%
Nonidet P-40) containing aprotinin (1 g/mL), leupeptin (1 g/mL),
10 mM sodium orthovanadate, 10 mM NaF, and 1 mM phenylmeth-
ylsulfonylfluoride was then added, and the cells were scraped off and
transferred into 1.5-mL microcentrifugation tubes. They were then
incubated on ice and vortexed for 20 s. After centrifugation at
100,000 g at 4°C for 20 min, the supernatants were obtained. The
protein content of each cell lysate was measured using a standard
spectrophotometric protein concentration assay (Bio-Rad). Protein
samples were then diluted with RIPA buffer to equalize protein
concentrations in all samples (1 mg/mL). Protein lysates were then
boiled for 5 min in 6  Laemmli buffer and 30 g of protein was
loaded into each well and separated by 7.5% (pRb and -actin) or 12%
(ERK-2 and pERK) sodium dudecyl sulfate–polyacrylanide gel elec-
trophoresis. The gels were run at 80 V for approximately 2 h. Pro-
teins were electroblotted onto a nitrocellulose membrane at 40 V
overnight at 4°C, and the membrane blocked in 5% nonfat dry milk
in Tris-buffered saline containing 0.05% Tween 20 for 30 mins.
Membranes were blotted with various primary antibodies for 2 h
followed by the appropriate horseradish peroxidase-conjugated sec-
ondary antibody for 45 min. The membrane was then treated with
the chemiluminescence kit, wrapped in plastic, and visualized on
radiographic film. Densitometry was performed using standard Na-
tional Institute of Health software.
Statistical Analysis
Each experiment was repeated a minimum of three times. Statis-
tical analyses were performed by one-way analysis of variance with
comparison against control, with Bonferroni adjustments for multi-
ple comaparisons. Data are presented as mean  standard deviation.
A value of P  0.05 was considered to be statistically significant.
RESULTS
VEGF Inhibits Mitogen-Induced Proliferation of VSMCs
A BrdU proliferation assay was used to assess pro-
liferation in human aortic smooth muscle cells. VEGF
inhibited PPDGF-BB-induced VSMC proliferation in a
dose-dependent manner and significantly reduced pro-
liferation from 40  9% with PDGF-BB at a concentra-
tion of 20 ng/mL to 36  12, 29  13, 23  10, 9  6,
and 5  5% of baseline (serum-starved conditions) at a
VEGF concentration of 10, 20, 30, (P  0.05), 40 (P 
0.05), and 50 ng/mL (P  0.01), respectively (Fig. 1).
Results are reported as mean  SD.
Cell Viability
Cell viability, as assessed by trypan blue exclusion,
was 98% at each time point with and without VEGF.
There was no evidence of cell death or necrosis based
on trypan blue testing.

VEGF Inhibits Phosphorylation of Rb
Western immunoblotting for phosphorylation of Rb
was used to assess cell cycle progression from G1 to S
phase. Cell cycle progression is represented by an in-
crease in the amount of phosphorylated Rb protein.
VEGF inhibited PDGF-BB-induced Rb phosphoryla-
tion in a dose-dependent manner (Fig. 2A). -actin
western immunoblot densitometry was performed to
confirm equivalent protein loading in each lane. Den-
sitometry revealed significant inhibition of Rb phos-
phorylation from 1.9- 0.2%-fold increase above base-
line with PDGF-BB at a concentration of 20 ng/mL to
1.5  0.19-, 1.3  0.16-, 1.1  0.02-, 1.0  0.08-, and 0.8
 0.05%-fold increase above baseline at a VEGF con-
centration of 10, 20, 30, 40 (P  0.05) and 50 ng/mL (P
 0.01), respectively (Fig. 2B). Results are reported as
mean  SD.
VEGF Inhibits Phosphorylation of ERK 1/2 Protein
ERK 1/2 phosphorylation was used to determine
whether VEGF inhibits cell signaling by PDGF-BB
through the MAPK pathway. Cell signaling as result of
PDGF-BB-induced stimulation resulted in an increase
of phosphorylation of ERK 1/2 protein. VEGF inhibited
PDGF-BB-induced ERK 1/2 phosphorylation in a dose-
dependent manner (Fig. 3A). ERK 2 western immuno-
blot densitometry did not demonstrate a significant
difference in loading between each lane. Densitometry
revealed significant inhibition of ERK 1/2 phosphory-
lation from 1.5- 0.17-fold increase above baseline
with PDGF-BB at a concentration of 20 ng/mL to 1.3 

CONCLUSION
Previous studies have determined that VEGF has
vascular protective effects as well as a role in thera-
peutic angiogenesis. In a rat carotid balloon injury
model, delivery of intravenous VEGF protein or VEGF
gene transfer was shown to accelerate re-
endothelialization and attenuate neointimal hyperpla-
sia [26, 27]. Further experiments studying stent im-
plantation in rabbit iliac arteries have shown that
intravenous VEGF protein or gene transfer accelerated
re-endothelialization, decreased neointima formation,
and reduced mural thrombosis [28, 29]. There is also
evidence of reduction in rabbit vein graft intimal hy-
perplasia following topical VEGF administration [36].
However, this issue has been the subject of consider-
able debate, since, for instance, it has been reported
that intravenous VEGF protein infusion in dogs after
iliofemoral balloon denudation actually resulted in in-
creased neointimal hyperplasia and had no effect on
maximal collateral blood flow [37]. Additionally, an-

phosphorylation of ERK 1/2 protein. Shown is the mean densitometry values ( SD) derived from three independent experiments compared

other group of investigators found that administration
of VEGF by various techniques did not increase endo-
thelial cell regrowth post denudation of either the
aorta or the carotid arteries of rats and mice, but only
increased vascular permeability [38].
Despite the above controversy, a significant body of
evidence points to VEGF being able to promote re-
endothelialization and reduce neointimal hyperplasia
after balloon-induced catheter injury, stent implanta-
tion and after vein grafting. Asahari et al. have hypoth-
esized that the mechanism by which VEGF inhibits
neointimal hyperplasia is principally through its pro-
liferating action on endothelial cells leading to the
re-endothelialization of denuded arteries, and that this
re-endothelialization secondarily inhibits neointimal
hyperplasia [26]. However, in an experiment per-
formed using an extravascular silastic collar to induce
VSMC proliferation (without endothelial cell denuda-
tion) in rabbit carotid arteries, it was discovered that
soaking the collar with VEGF gene, and using the cuff
as a gene delivery reservoir significantly inhibited neo-
intimal VSMC hyperplasia [39]. This implies that
VEGF may have vascular protective effects indepen-
dent of its mitogenic action on endothelial cells.
Interestingly, Taniguchi et al. demonstrated that, in
a cell culture model using human uterine myometrial
cells, addition of VEGF-neutralizing antibody to
PDGF-BB stimulated cells resulted in a linear increase
in proliferation beyond plateau maximal concentra-
tions of PDGF-BB [40]. They hypothesized that VEGF
may negatively regulate the myometrial cell prolifera-
tion induced by PDGF-BB. In that particular study, the
investigators did not perform any further experiments
to elucidate the mechanism by which VEGF might be
suppressing PDGF-BB induced proliferation. Addition-
ally, Hu et al. reported that VEGF-2, which differs
from VEGF protein by one amino acid residue within
the signal peptide portion, inhibits PDGF-BB induced
human aortic cell proliferation. The authors also hy-
pothesized that VEGF-2 may have a regulatory action
on the vasculature [41].
Our experiments clearly demonstrate that VEGF
has a direct effect on mitogen-induced proliferation of
VSMC. PDGF was used as a known VSMC mitogen
because it has been shown in previous studies to play
an important role in the pathogenesis of the neointimal
lesion [9 –12]. Using the BrdU proliferation assay, we
have shown that when PDGF induces the proliferation
of VSMC, VEGF inhibits DNA synthesis in a dose-
dependent manner. Furthermore, western immuno-
assay reveals that the inhibition of proliferation is
paralleled by a dose-dependent decrease in Rb phos-
phorylation. This implies that the VSMCs are unable
to pass from the G1 to the S phase of the cell cycle and
thus were in cell cycle arrest. In addition, ERK phos-
phorylation was also inhibited in a dose-dependent
manner suggesting that VEGF has effects upstream
from ERK phosphorylation in the MAPK cascade. Fur-
ther studies are necessary to determine the exact point
of action of VEGF in the MAPK pathway, and whether
it acts through its own Flt-1 or Flk-1/KDR receptor or
whether it acts as a PDGF antagonist at the receptor
level. The latter may be a more likely mechanism be-
cause VEGF has a similar 3-D structure to PDGF-BB
and also has a related amino acid sequence [42]. Addi-
tional investigations are required to determine
whether VEGF induces apoptosis in VSMC. Apoptosis,
however, is unlikely to be the explanation for the de-
creased proliferation of VSMC to PDGF-BB in the pres-
ence of VEGF because there was no evidence of nonvi-
able or dead cells at any of the time points or treatment
arms, as evidenced by the trypan blue exclusion test.
However, this particular piece of data is a gross, but
inadequate test to rule cell death as a cause of the
observed phenomenon and will have to be confirmed by
detailed investigation into morphologic features of and
other markers of apoptosis.
In summary, we have demonstrated that VEGF may
have direct inhibitory effects on VSMC proliferation
and that this occurs in the absence of endothelial cells.
This occurs upstream of ERK in the MAPK pathway.
In addition to re-endothelialization, we believe that
this is another important vascular protective mecha-
nism of VEGF in modulating mitogen-induced VSMC
proliferation following vascular injury and in attenu-
ating the development of neointimal hyperplasia.
Moreover, VEGF may act as a negative feedback reg-
ulator of mitogen-induced VSMC proliferation. Fur-
ther investigation is necessary to better understand
the exact mechanism of action, so that, perhaps, new
insight may be gained into the interaction between
PDGF and VEGF and the role that each may play in a
regulatory response to arterial injury.
